title: CEO Lessons: Running Towards Fear, Managerial Leverage, and Making Unpopular Decisions
description: Ben Horowitz, co-founder of Andreessen Horowitz, shares lessons on CEO decision-making under pressure, why hesitation is deadly, the Good Product Manager framework, managerial leverage, not judging people by worst moments, and why AI isn't a bubble.
summary: Ben discusses success as a series of small good decisions (pilot story), running towards fear because hesitation locks up companies, making unpopular decisions (only value CEOs add), Good Product Manager as leadership not tasks, managerial leverage (team tells you what to do), not judging people on worst moments (Adam Neumann), confidence being critical for founders, and why AI isn't a financial bubble unlike dot-com.

key_themes.description: Hesitation is the worst thing leaders do - both options are horrible but one is slightly better, make the decision
If everyone agrees with your decision, you added no value - leaders exist to make calls most people don't like
As CEO you don't make people great, you find people that make you great - they tell you what to do, not vice versa

key_themes.theme: Success Is Series of Small Decisions
key_themes.description: Narrative says one smart thing led to success, reality is small hard decisions compound into outcomes

key_insights.quote: The worst thing that you do as a leader is you hesitate on the next decision. The thing that causes you to hesitate is both decisions are horrible. Probably one of my bigger ones on that was we went public with $2 million in trailing 12 months revenue at 18 months old. That's obviously a bad idea. But the truth of it was the alternative was going bankrupt, and that's a worse idea.
key_insights.context: Opening quote about decision-making under pressure
key_insights.insight: When both options are terrible, hesitating is worse than choosing the slightly better horrible option

key_insights.quote: The psychological muscle you have to build to be a great leader is to be able to click in the abyss and go, 'Okay, that way's slightly better. We're going to go that way.' If everybody agrees with the decision, then you didn't add any value because they would've done that without you.
key_insights.insight: Leaders only add value when making decisions most people don't like - consensus decisions didn't need you

key_insights.quote: All plane crashes are a series of bad decisions. And none of the decisions by themselves is that bad, but when you add them up, it's bad. It's one decision leads to another. And so if you can break psychologically, you can take the sunk cost, then that gets you out of a lot of bad paths.
key_insights.insight: Success/failure is series of small decisions - cut sunk costs early to avoid bad decision chains

key_insights.quote: All the things that you perceive that are happening to you that are bad, be it the systems against you or somebody undercuts you or racism or sexism, is very small compared to what you do to yourself. If you believe what people say about you, if you believe what they did to you, then that destroys you.
key_insights.context: Shaka's lesson about what held him back
key_insights.insight: What you believe about yourself matters more than external circumstances - don't let others define you

key_insights.quote: A lot of getting people not to hesitate is just getting them over that. Often, early in a CEO's career, a lot of it is just not knowing how to have the conversation.
key_insights.context: Coaching CEOs through difficult conversations like firing
key_insights.insight: CEOs hesitate because they don't know how to have the hard conversation - coach them on the words

key_insights.quote: You've got to be able to tell them the truth in a way that you probably don't tell most of your friends the truth. You say tell people what they want to hear, but in dealing at a company level, you've got to be able to tell them what they don't want to hear. That's the most important thing you're going to say.
key_insights.insight: Respect means telling hard truths, not making people comfortable - that's what saves companies

key_insights.quote: The only reason to start a company is because you have an irrational desire to do so, because it's not worth the money. When we sold LoudCloud for $1.6 billion, I remember thinking, 'Wow, that wasn't worth the money whatsoever.'
key_insights.context: Advice on who should start companies
key_insights.insight: Don't start a company for money - need irrational desire to improve the world, nothing else gets you through

key_insights.quote: You don't make people great. You find people that make you great, that make the company great, that you learned from, not the other way around. If I have the ideas about what your department should do next, that's no leverage. What's leverage is if you're telling me what you should do, then I'm getting more than I'd have if you weren't there.
key_insights.context: Advice to Ali Ghodsi becoming CEO of Databricks
key_insights.insight: Managerial leverage = hiring people who tell you what to do, not people you have to push forward

key_insights.quote: What happens is if you lose confidence, you hesitate on the next decision. And if you have senior people working for you, they get very nervous and they feel like they need to jump into that void and make the decision for you. That's when it gets political, very political.
key_insights.insight: Confidence → hesitation → power vacuum → politics → dysfunction - confidence is critical

key_insights.quote: The difficult part is the feeling that you have when you have to do it. The hard thing of doing a reorg is you're redistributing power, so you're going to have people really mad at you. Dealing with that is the hard thing. Knowing how the organization should work to make communication better, it's not that complex.
key_insights.context: Why management is hard despite simple concepts
key_insights.insight: Management techniques are 8th grade level - the hard part is dealing with emotions when executing them

key_insights.quote: You don't judge a person by the worst thing that ever happened to them. We've all had bad things happen to us. You want to judge people on what they do well, not what they screwed up, because that's where you see the talent.
key_insights.insight: Judge people on their strengths, not their worst moment - that's where real talent shows

key_insights.quote: The job is fundamentally a leadership job. And it's a tricky leadership job because nobody is actually reporting to you. Your actual job is to get a product into market that customers love that's better than anything that anybody else in the world puts in market. And all the other things are tasks that you may or may not need to do.
key_insights.context: Explaining Good Product Manager, Bad Product Manager
key_insights.insight: PM is leadership without authority - job is shipping beloved products, everything else is just tasks

key_insights.quote: The thing that people got very wrong is this whole thin wrapper around GPT. Back in the '80s, that same phrase was used, but it was thin wrapper around an RDBMS. So it meant companies like Salesforce were basically just a thin wrapper. At Cursor, they've built 14 different models to really understand how a developer works.
key_insights.insight: 'Thin wrapper' criticism ignores deep domain modeling required - same mistake made about Salesforce in '80s

key_insights.quote: In order for it to be a bubble, you need capitulation. You need everybody to believe it's not a bubble, because then the prices really go out of control. As long as there's people who think it's a bubble, it's hard for that to happen.
key_insights.context: Whether AI is in a bubble
key_insights.insight: When everyone thinks it's a bubble, it's not a bubble - bubbles need universal belief

key_insights.quote: If you're a CEO listening to this, then know that how you feel about yourself is going to end up meaning as much as anything. From this day on, no credit will be given for predicting rain, only credit for building an ark.
key_insights.insight: Self-evaluation matters most - predicting failure gets you nothing, only building the ark counts
